Karazin Kharkiv National University, Svoboda Square 4 Kharkiv 61022 Ukraine The aim of this research was to comprehensively analyze zinc ferro- and ferri-cyanides for rationally choose or modify hexacyanoferrates in a range of application focused on catalysing the ring-opening copolymerization of epoxides and CO2 to reduce the environmental toll. Scripts of the synthesis of 14 samples with variable morphology are given. Thermogravimetry, FT-IR, and XRD indicates the formation of two predominant types of bridging cyanide groups with different coordination environment, which accounts for a lack crystallinity aggregate with an amorphous part. Involving dynamic light scattering and laser Doppler electrophoresis as distinguishing features the formation of colloidal fractions is demonstrated and characterized. The switch from a negative surface rich in Lewis basic sites (Me–CN–) to a surface rich in open-metal sites is either jump and stepwise successfully completed. The proposed structures of micelles of the catalysts allow great attention to be paid to every small detail of their catalytic activity. Graphical Abstract Keywords Prussian blue analogue Cyanometallate Double metal cyanide Cyano metal complex Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The demand for the transition metal hexacyanometallates family continues to grow due to the diversity of their wide range of applications. The current list includes areas such as heterogeneous catalysis, batteries, photochemistry, sensors, supercapacitors, molecular magnets, electrochromic devices, hydrogen storage, water splitting, smart windows, proton conduction, negativethermal expansion, selective ion exchangers, multifunctional probes, therapeutic agents, drug delivery, etc. [1–6]. Although all of the above-mentioned areas share a common structure-activity relationship, the focus of this paper is on the first one. Double metal cyanides, DMC, are heterogeneous catalysts for ring-opening polymerizations of epoxides [7]; ring-opening copolymerization, especially epoxides and CO2 [8]; phosphoramidate synthesis [9]; intermolecular hydroaminations [10]. Kinetic parameters and quantitative characterization have been presented in [5,7,11–13]. For example, synthesis of polyglycidols by ringopening multibranching polymerization of glycidol in the absence of any initiators was characterised by yields of <1 % and 80–90 % at reaction time of 24 h and 5 h using ZnCl2 and DMC catalysts, respectively [14]. However, hexacyanometallates are poorly represented in the works of fundamental researchers, which leads to the fact that the mechanism of their influence is not entirely clear. As the latter allows improving the effectiveness of their use, we have taken such a task. Recently, the crystal and electronic structures have been established [15,16]. Nitrogen weakly antibonding 5σ orbital of CN– is a σ-donor; such donation increases in Me–CN– at higher charge on the central metal [4,17]. This forms Lewis basic sites of hexacyanometallates, which is the coordination site for the other metal. Interaction with transition metal dications creates open-metal sites with an electron-deficient incomplete coordination sphere, which act as Lewis acid [8]. This results in overlapping electron clouds of neighboring metal centers. On the reagent side of things, an epoxide ring-opening involves a polarization of the C–O σ-bond of the epoxide by O–Me coordination of nonbonding electron pair of the oxygen to the Lewis acid center of catalyst (a preactivation of the ring toward nucleophilic opening) [18,19]. Enhanced binding energy of CO2 to an open-metal site of catalyst is expected if the σ*-antibonding orbitals between the CO2 lone pair and d-orbitals of metal are empty [6]. Incomplete coordination sphere of open-metal sites is attractive for water molecule as Lewis base [2,19]. In [20] it is argued that the presence of water in zeolites significantly blocked access for CO2, but water bound to metal-organic framework Cu-BTC increases CO2 adsorption. On the other hand, the basic co-solvent in the catalyst synthesis as a ligand should affect its structure. Note Lewis basic sites of porous hexacyanometallates allows H2 stabilization for the gas storage [1]. Cyanometallates synthesis is described as an ion-exchange reaction between metal cyanide complexes and transition metal salt without going into details of observations [3,8,21,22]. The crystalline phase is usually collected as sediment, which is washed intensively. In the case of zinc ferricyanide synthesis, we clearly observed two layers of precipitate with different colors (see below). One of them contains particles that pass through paper filters, so this fraction can be missed. There are the following empirical conclusions (i) the highly crystalline Zn3[Co(CN)6]2 prepared in the absence of a complexing agent has not catalytic activity in the propylene oxide polymerization; (ii) free ZnCl2 increases the catalytic activity of hexacyanometallates; (iii) the induction period is longer in excess amount of free ZnCl2; (iv) free ZnCl2 has not catalytic activity in propylene oxide polymerization [5], but ZnX2/(n-Bu4N)X salts have it to the coupling of monosubstituted oxiranes to cyclic carbonates [23]; (v) the most effective zinc halide is ZnBr2 with respect to the activity of catalyst and induction period [5]; (vi) a small amount of the epoxide activates the catalysts before the polymerizing process [5]; (vi) incorporating complexing agents controls the catalytic activity through structure of the catalysts [24]; (vii) complexing agent as polyether and t-butyl alcohol made more noncrystalline and amorphous catalysts with small crystal particle; (viii) excess zinc chloride increases the chlorine content in the DMC catalyst, which cannot be easy to remove during the preparation of the catalysts, and decreases of the relative content of crystalline structure [24]; (ix) the catalyst heating over 2 h at above 100 °C without epoxide can increase its activity [21]. Summarizing, the synthesis with t-butyl alcohol and excess of chloride salts of inner metal reduces the degree of crystallinity and particle size as well as increases the three-dimensional and surface defects of the catalyst. Such synthesis procedure is associated with high activity of cyanometallate catalysts. We aimed to explain the relationships zinc ferro- and ferri-cyanides structures and synthesis procedure from the point of view of colloid chemistry involving analysis via dynamic light scattering, DLS, and laser Doppler electrophoresis, LDE; more universal methods were also involved. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Material Potassium hexacyanoferrate (III) (99 % of the main substance, Sigma-Aldrich), potassium hexacyanoferrate (II) trihydrate (extra pure, Merck/Supelco), and zinc nitrate hexahydrate (99 % of the main substance, Thermo Fisher Scientific) were used as received. The reactants solutions were prepared dissolving an appropriate amount of a salt. Volume fraction of t-butanol corresponds to volume of alcohol per volume of the solution. The experimental procedure was created at room temperature, 25 °C. 2.2 Synthesis procedure Each synthesis according to the scripts described below was proceed by synchronous dropwise addition of solutions ‘A’ and ‘B’ to 100 mL of reaction medium for 10 min using a magnetic stirrer and 20 min of additional stirring (some deviations in the procedure are noted). The system was then centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 5 min. To remove the excess free ions, the pellet was resuspended in 50 mL deionized water and centrifuged five times at 5000 rpm for 5 min. The precipitate was dried 3 h at 200 °C. The Scripts: IB. The molar ratio of Zn(NO 3 ) 2 to K 3 [Fe(CN) 6 ] was 0.1 in an aqueous t-butanol system. 0.2975 g Zn(NO3)2×6 H2O was dissolved in t-butanol to 10 mL (solution A). 3.2924 g K3[Fe(CN)6] was dissolved in water to 10 mL (solution B). The identities and crystallographic information were characterized via X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) using a Rigaku Miniflex X-ray diffractometer. X-ray generator operated at 40 kV and 15 mA; scan mode was 1D(scan); scan speed/duration time was 4.00 °/min; goniometer was miniFlex 300/600; step width was 0.02°; scan range was 3–90°. Dynamic Light Scattering was used to estimation of the average hydrodynamic size and zeta-potential of dispersed phase and was performed using a Zetasizer Nano ZS Malvern Instrument apparatus at scattering angle of 173° and 13° at 25 °C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Thermogravimetric (TG) data Based on TG data ( Fig. 1 and Table S1), it seems that lattice solvent molecules were removed when the samples were dried at 200 °C according the synthesis procedure. The FT-IR spectra of ferricyanides samples (except sample IIB′) correspond to this ( Fig. 2). In the case of the ferrocyanides and sample IIB′, a step on the TG curves at <200 °C demonstrates a more pronounced hygroscopicity in comparison to the other samples. The latter is confirmed by the bands in FT-IR spectrum that arise from water (ν(OH) = 3627 cm–1 and δ(HOH) = 1609 cm–1 [27,28]) and do not appear from CO2 (∼2342 cm–1 [29]) and t-butanol [30]. The step on TG curve ending at ∼180 °C with mass loss of 7 %, 9 %, and 10 % quantifies this for IIB′, VIIW, and VIIB samples, respectively. The steps on the TG curve at >200 °C refer to pyrolysis. Generally, the decomposition temperature depends on outer metals. In this manner Prussian White decomposition under Ar flow starts (i) at >500 °C with the release of cyanogen gas if Na cations content is 1.5, and (ii) at around 300 °C as partial decomposition if Na cations content is zero [31]. A release of cyanide groups from Prussian Blue nanoparticles was detected within two steps at average temperatures of 308, 352, 608, and 643 °C [32]. Multistage mass loss pyrolysis can be attributed to the decomposition of complex anions with different coordination environments, which may be due to the amorphization of the crystal phase. Some increase in the decomposition temperature of samples from I to V may be related to the high percentage of Zn–CN strong bonds in sample V, since this sample was obtained under conditions of excess zinc cations. 3.2 Analysis of FT-IR data In general, CN– is a good σ-donor (nitrogen weakly antibonding 5σ-orbital) and a poor π-acceptor (antibonding 2pπ*-orbital) combined with its negative charge and ambidentate ligand ability. The CN ligand is able to serve as a bridge between neighboring metal centers, removing electron density from the metal linked to its C-end via a π-back-bonding interaction to increase the charge density at the N-end, which is the coordination site for the other metal. This results in overlapping electron clouds of neighboring metal centers [4,17]. The stretching bands of cyanocomplexes have been thoroughly described in [17,33]. The FT-IR spectrum of hexacyanometallates family is characterized by next motions: δ(Me–CN), ν(Me–C), and ν(CN). The absorbed water on such structures can be defined as two modes of vibration: δ(HOH) and ν(OH) around 1600 cm–1 and 3400–3600 cm–1, respectively [1,8]. Free CN–, K4[Fe(CN)6], and K3[Fe(CN)6] show ν(CN) band at 2080 cm−1 [17], 2048 cm−1 [8], and 2121 cm−1 [7]. σ-Donation from nitrogen weakly antibonding 5σ-orbital to the metal tends to shift the ν(CN) band towards higher frequencies, whereas π-back-bonding sifts towards lower [7,34]. The donor and acceptor abilities of CN are governed by the electronegativity and oxidation state of the metal. The lowest electronegativity or oxidation state of central metal leads to the lowest σ-donation [34]. Reducing the valence of the outer cation has a smaller effect [35]. Thus, the ν(CN) band is an excellent sensor of the complex formation. The bands of the dried ferricyanide samples in the 1950–2250 cm–1 and 530–630 cm–1 ranges are presented in Fig. 2 and Table 1. The characteristic band of K4[Fe(CN)6] and K3[Fe(CN)6] disappeared from the IR spectrums. The appearance of two ν(CN) bands proves the formation of two predominant types of bridging cyanide groups with different coordination environment. Analyzing the dried ferricyanide samples, the peak at 2186 cm–1 is attributed to zinc tetrahedrally coordinated to N-ends of the CN ligands in hexagonal phases, which provides relatively high thermal stability and a porous framework since both metal centers saturated their coordination sphere with atoms from the bridging group [17,28]. Before drying the sample, the peak was at 2162 cm–1, which corresponds to a higher coordination number of zinc due to the involving coordination of solvent molecules and some decrease in zinc charge, resulting in a reduced effect on σ-donation [28]. A small shoulder absorption at this wavenumber also appears on the spectrum of the dry samples; in [28] the peak at 2162 cm–1 was attributed to zinc atom in octahedral coordination of cubic zinc ferricyanide. The peak at 2096 cm–1 in the dried sample corresponds to a weak influence of the outer cation on the σ-donation as well as π-back-bonding formation with outer cation. In [17,34], a peak at this wavenumber was observed for zinc having a distorted octahedral arrangement with two cyano and complexing agents. This zinc can be considered as an "innocent" cation that coordinate to the terminal nitrogen end of the ligand, such cations state has already been ascribed for salts of sodium, potassium, manganese, iron, and cobalt [33]. The short-frequency ν(CN) band emerges clearer with decreasing zinc salt concentration in the synthesis, i.e. from V to I samples, which is also accompanied by an increase in the fraction of yellow precipitate. It was of interest to separate this fraction (see Script IIB′). Comparing of IR spectrum of sample IIB′ and others ferricyanide samples showed that the transmittance increases sharply at 2096 cm–1 and 602 cm–1 as well as some at 2162 cm–1. The TG curve is different from other obtained ferricyanides and demonstrates the hygroscopicity of this sample. The absorption maximum at 422 nm of the aqueous dispersion of sample IIB′ (420 nm characteristic peak of potassium ferricyanide) is probably due to more terminal nitrogen end of the ligand with coordinated "innocent" cations and some potassium, as indicated by the XRD data. The zinc-rich fraction, which is poorly dispersible in pure water, has orange color, which may be due to a charge-transfer transition resulting from the influence of stronger coordinated zinc in coordination polymer. The white precipitate of ferrocyanide samples VIIB and VIIW emphasizes the weaker σ-donation from the CN− group compered to ferricyanides. In a ferrocyanide samples, CN groups with zinc octahedral or tetrahedral coordinated to N-ends correspond to ν(CN) = 2095 cm–1 [28] and 2108 cm–1 [1], respectively. The obtained dried samples show an intense band at lower wavenumbers (2087 cm–1 and 2090 cm–1 for VIIW and VIIB samples), which, along with the emerging δ(HOH) and ν(OH) bands observed around 1609 cm–1 and 3630 cm–1 (Fig. S7), may correspond to that zinc also coordinates the solvent molecules. For example, in Zn2[Fe(CN)6]×3 H2O nanocubes, ν(CN) is more shifted to 2080 cm–1 [36]. However, the ν(CN) of ferrocyanide does not depend strongly on the zinc coordination number [17,33]. The bands at 2087 cm–1 and 2090 cm–1 for samples VIIW and VIIB are broad and may be attributed to coordination with "innocent" cations. Small band at 2162 cm–1 may be corresponding to cyano-bridge in coordination polymer. Comparing the FT-IR spectra of the samples prepared in aqueous and the alcohol solution, it can be conclude that t-butanol increases the fraction of "innocent" cations that coordinate to the terminal nitrogen end of the ligand. 3.3 Analysis of XRD data In the next stage, XRD technique was applied to dried samples. Figs. S13 and S14 show corresponding diffractograms. Data analysis in the SmartLab software included peak fitting, a full width at half maximum, FWHM, computation, database pattern matching, and calculation of crystallite size and d-spacing. Some details of the samples are collected in Table 2. Williamson–Hall plots of obtained data are non-linear, which is often due to the existence of multiple phases in the sample. The smaller diameter is characterized by ferrocyanide and ferricyanide samples with a high fraction of yellow precipitate. In general, the particle size in the samples obtained in the presence of t-butanol is slightly smaller than in the alcohol-free system. This indicates that the formation of the crystalline structure of the sample is impaired by the addition of tertiary alcohol. In [37] a decrease in the particle size was also observed when a mixture of water and formamide was used. The sample composition based on the XRD analysis was evaluated in Rigaku SmartLab software by comparing its pattern with those of candidate materials searched in database. The patterns of samples IB, IW, IIB, IIW, IIIB, and IIIW are matching 100 % with a database pattern of zinc hexacyanoferrate. The width of the peaks corresponds to a lack of long-range order in the crystal lattices caused by crystal imperfections. Some zinc–iron cyanide was detected in XRD data of samples VB and VW along with zinc hexacyanoferrate (Figs. S13 and S14). The samples IIB′, VIIB, and VIIW correspond most notably patterns with features of a substantially percentages of potassium–iron cyanide. Addition of Zn(NO3)2 to the dispersion of sample IIB′, resulting in sample VI, leads to an increase in particle size and changes its composition to 100 % zinc hexacyanoferrate. 3.4 Analysis of dynamic light scattering and laser Doppler electrophoresis data To get more information about the morphology of the samples, DLS analysis was applied to their colloidal suspensions. The open-metal sites and Lewis basic sites of hexacyanometallates are charged, which should be reflected in the surface charge, thus the LDE analysis was also involved. The dried samples (0.03 g) were resuspended in 15 mL salt-free water with ultrasound 3 intervals: 30, 15 and 15 min, and centrifuged at 1000 rpm for 1 min. The size of particles after resuspension was determined as average hydrodynamic size by dynamic light scattering technology (Z-average, which is the intensity-weighted average value of the ensemble collection of particles). In salt-free water, the highly crystalline precipitate fraction should not be peptized. Even after resuspension, the size of colloidal particles is smaller than the pores of the filter paper. Comparison of the Z-average and the size obtained by XRD indicated that micron-sized particles with a weak negative zeta potential ( Table 3) should be attributed to agglomerates of primary nanoparticles. The zeta potential increases with increasing zinc salt concentration used in the synthesis of the samples. The lowest zeta potential along with smallest particles is found in potassium-rich samples, i.e. samples IIB′, VIIB, and VIIW, nevertheless their hydrodynamic size is larger than the crystallite size ( Fig. 3). The samples obtained in the presence of t-butanol characterise more negative zeta potential. Addition of Zn(NO3)2 to the dispersion of sample IIB′, i.e. sample VI, leads to an increase in particle size (Fig. 3) and zeta potential (Table 3) and is consistent with the adsorption of zinc cations on the primary negatively charged particles of sample IIB′, leading to colloidal instability of the dispersion. 4 Conclusions DMC catalyst is usually represented as Zn a [Fe(CN)6] b ×ZnCl2×yH2O×xComplexing agents [38–40] based on elemental analysis data. However, free ZnCl2 in the catalyst was not detected by XRD performed in [12,24]. In contrast to crystalline Zn3[Fe(CN)6] insoluble in water, in terms of colloid chemistry a lack crystallinity aggregate with an amorphous part forms a structural unit of colloidal solution – a micelle. Its structure is as follows: (I) Cations Zn2+ adsorbed on the crystalline aggregate and chloride ions as counter-ions form a double electrical layer. The chloride ions of the Stern layer have relatively lower kinetic energy and cannot be detected potentiometrically [41]. The counter-ions of the diffuse layer are a part of the bulk solution due to osmotic force. The role of Cl– ions in catalytic activity is a matter of discussion; their presence has been shown to be necessary for the preparation of highly active cyanometallate catalysts for both ring-opening polymerizations and copolymerization [24]. Representation of the catalyst structure as micelles demonstrates that Cl– ions may indicate a zinc coordination sphere unsaturated by N-end of hexacyanoferrate. In present research, the choice of zinc salt was determined by the possibility of identifying the nitrate by FT-IR. Since no bands of nitrate ions arised (Fig. 2), the formation of micelle (I) cannot be confirmed and nitrate ions was removed by 5-fold washing. The particle charge of micelle (I) should result in a positive zeta potential, which is not actually observed. The TGA, XRD, and FT-IR data indicate the presence of complex anions with various coordination environments. Empirical evidence of the DLS and LDE methods, supplemented Vis-absorption spectroscopy, indicates the formation of nanosized particles forming a colloidal solution in water. The main fraction of colloidal particles in samples VIIB and VIIW can be represented by micelle (II) taking into account the XRD results for potassium content (Table 2) and the LDE data for negative zeta potential (Table 3). Although the molar ratio of Zn(NO3)2 to K4[Fe(CN)6] was 1, σ-donation from the CN− group of ferrocyanide coordinates zinc weaker than ferricyanides, leading to structures rich in Lewis basic sites and small crystallite size. Weak coordination of zinc to ferricyanide in aggregate of micelle should also accounts Lewis acid sites. In [8] gas-solid phase titration of amorphous Zn2[Fe(CN)6] with NH3 revealed a high density of acid sites, but the catalyst showed mild activity in ring‑opening copolymerization of CO2 and propylene oxide. Some indirect evidences showed that the catalytic active sites were of coordination and cationic nature [21]. In contrast, Zn3[Fe(CN)6]2 exhibited higher catalytic activity [13]. Though incompletely coordination sphere, this open-metal sites are attractive for water molecule as Lewis base [2,19]; the hygroscopicity of the samples mentioned above based on TG and FT-IR data is characteristic for potassium-rich samples with high negative zeta potential. Density functional theory modeling predicts orientation the water and hydronium H atoms towards the cyanide N atoms, but only the charged species are able to form bonds with the CN groups [42]. The coordination way of complexing agent such as the dicarbonyl ligands, to protect open-metal sites from occupation by water molecules during preparation of the catalyst, may also affect the active sites formation and the polymerization pathways [43]. (II) In this investigation t-butanol was used as complexing agent. The Mayer acceptor numbers are 27.1 and 54.8, and the Gutmann donor numbers are 38 and 33 for t-butanol and water, respectively [44]. The acceptor ability of t-butanol cannot enhance anions coordination in aqueous t-butanol solution. However, it can influence the packing of water molecules around an anion. A stronger donor ability of t-butanol displaces H2O from the cation solvation sphere. The role of t-butanol in the synthesis is probably to act as a sterically bulky ligand to zinc cations, which shields zinc from the complex ion. Therefore, the zeta potential of such samples and the size according to XRD are lower than those obtained in an alcohol-free system. As indicated above, zeta potential was obtained for washed dry sediment resuspended in salt-free water. During the synthesis at high cation concentration, compression of the electric double layer leads to coagulation after critical electrolyte concentration. The large volume of the reaction medium used in the experiment favored the production of small particles. This, along with the negative ζ value, determines their good dispersibility. Analyzing the ferricyanides sample, the negative charge of the fraction of colloidal particles along with the absence of nitrate on the FT-IR spectra indicates that the role of potential determining ions is also played by [Fe(CN)6]3– which arises at 2096 cm–1 on FT-IR spectra. However, the zeta potential, hydrodynamic size and size according to XRD are greater and the amount of potassium according to XRD is less than those of ferrocyanides samples VIIB and VIIW. This is consistent with the stronger σ-donation of [Fe(CN)6]3–, which (i) contributes to the formation of many more Zn–NC strong bonds of coordination polymer in crystalline aggregate (see micelle (II)) that arises at 2186 cm–1 on FT-IR spectra, and (ii) promotes further chemisorption of zinc cations replacing potassium in the Stern layer with the formation of structure (III). Although, according to the XRD data that characterize the sample as a whole (the dispersible and non-dispersible fractions), potassium cations were detected only in sample IIB′. Thus, the two ν(CN) bands of ferricyanides correspond to two predominant types of bridging cyanide groups with different coordination environment. Potassium undetected in the samples attributes these peaks to the coordination of zinc cations affecting on σ-donation differently. Adsorbed zinc corresponds to coordinated zinc in the form of "innocent" cations. (III) The high concentration of zinc cations in synthesis of VB and VW samples leads to pronounced chemisorption of zinc cations and zinc–iron cyanide becomes detectable in the diffractogram (Table 2). The particle size some increases due to the growth of the coordination polymer, which is also accompanied by a decrease in the peak at 2096 cm–1. This followed by an increase in the zeta potential of the particles (Table 3) and leads to low colloidal stability. Such structures should provide the tight location of catalytic active sites. For example, there are two reactants in the reaction of ring-opening copolymerization, namely epoxides and CO2. Each ones interacts with catalyst active sites through Lewis acid and base interactions. O–Me coordination of the epoxide and the Lewis acid center of the catalyst leads to a polarization of the C–O σ-bond (a preactivation of the ring towards nucleophilic opening). CO2 adsorbed by donating a lone pair of electrons to electron acceptor site of open-metal. The tight location of catalytic active sites increases the probability of interaction between the reagents. Sample drying at ∼100 °C should create an incomplete coordination sphere of electron-deficient zinc that act as Lewis acid, so enhances the catalytic activity of such preactivated catalyst has been seen in [21]. Double metal cyanide complex obtained using K3Fe(CN)6 and Zn(CH3COO)2 has lower catalytic activity, but high selectivity due to the electron atmosphere and strong steric hindrance of bidentate acetate compere to the complex obtained using K3Fe(CN)6 and ZnCl2 [11]. The XRD data of sample IIB′ on the amount of potassium relate the ultramicroheterogeneous fraction of ferricyanide samples, obtained at low applied zinc salt concentrations, to micelle (III) with a low x value. This results in the lowest zeta potential among the ferricyanides, but slightly higher than that of the ferrocyanide samples. It is not excluded that negative micelles of ferrocyanides also correspond to structure (III) with a poor x value. Despite the hygroscopic nature of IIB′ sample based on TG data, the peak at 2162 cm–1 associated with the ν(CN) of crystalline aggregate with hydrated zinc is represented only as a shoulder, indicating that only a fraction of this zinc increases the coordination number involving coordination of solvent molecules. Sample VI confirms the displacement of potassium cations upon addition of the divalent metal salt to sample IIB′. Comparing the data of all applied methods before (sample IIB′) and after (sample VI) addition of zinc cations, a jump from a negative surface dominated by Lewis basic sites to the zero zeta potential of zinc-rich particles is evident. This result should not be overlooked for the rational choice or modification of hexacyanoferrates in a range of applications and enable the synthesis of transition metal hexacyanoferrate more effective as catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The aim of this research was to comprehensively analyze zinc ferro- and ferri-cyanides for rationally choose or modify hexacyanoferrates in a range of application focused on catalysing the ring-opening copolymerization of epoxides and CO2 to reduce the environmental toll. Scripts of the synthesis of 14 samples with variable morphology are given. Thermogravimetry, FT-IR, and XRD indicates the formation of two predominant types of bridging cyanide groups with different coordination environment, which accounts for a lack crystallinity aggregate with an amorphous part. Involving dynamic light scattering and laser Doppler electrophoresis as distinguishing features the formation of colloidal fractions is demonstrated and characterized. The switch from a negative surface rich in Lewis basic sites (Me–CN–) to a surface rich in open-metal sites is either jump and stepwise successfully completed. The proposed structures of micelles of the catalysts allow great attention to be paid to every small detail of their catalytic activity.
